Content_wSideColumn.BodyCopy:
Strengthen marriages and families

The Department of Home and Family provides a holistic approach to the study of home and family. The department teaches courses designed to strengthen students' testimonies in the gospel of Jesus Christ, teach doctrines and skills to help maintain and strengthen the home as the most effective place of instruction, and provide a well-balanced education for teaching the importance of home and family.

What are the classes like?

BYU-Idaho's online courses mirror campus courses. They follow the same semester format and use the learning model. Students will have regular due dates for assignments and should expect to interact with their instructors and peers often.

How long will this program take?

Our online degree program allows students the flexibility to finish their degree while balancing a busy life. Students who are just beginning their studies will be able to graduate with a B.S. in Marriage & Family Studies as early as Fall 2014. Students who have completed their generals can begin taking major-specific upper division credits during the Winter 2012 semester.

Students can accelerate to graduation by taking classes all three semesters each year, or take a semester off when needed. Students must complete the program within eight years.

What will I study?

  • Marriage and family studies
  • Family theories and dynamics
  • Child guidance
  • Child development
  • Home and family management

View all degree requirements in the University Catalog and check course availability.

Is this a good fit for me?

Where do I begin?

Students who meet the admission requirements can apply to be directly admitted into a online degree program. These students will start by taking the online orientation course, a one-credit course offered every block. This course prepares students to succeed online and charts a course to graduation. Pathway students who complete Academic Start do not need to take GS 111.
